articles.headline: For Sibling Survivors of a Mass Shooting, Christmas Is an Act of Resolve
articles.snippet: Charlene and James Slaugh were both wounded at Club Q. Families impacted by hundreds of mass shootings this year face a tough holiday season.
articles.abstract: Charlene and James Slaugh were both wounded at Club Q. Families impacted by hundreds of mass shootings this year face a tough holiday season.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Charlene Slaugh’s family insisted she did not have to bring presents to Christmas this year. Her survival, they said, was gift enough.

articles.headline: Russian Air Base Is Attacked, as Ukraine Discounts Escalation Threat
articles.snippet: Russia said falling wreckage from a Ukrainian drone had killed three servicemen at the base, some 300 miles from Ukraine, which would be the third such long-range attack this month.
articles.abstract: Russia said falling wreckage from a Ukrainian drone had killed three servicemen at the base, some 300 miles from Ukraine, which would be the third such long-range attack this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine launched a drone attack at an air base deep within Russian territory, killing three servicemen, the Kremlin said on Monday, as Kyiv’s forces demonstrated that they are increasingly willing and able to take the fight to Russia, and at longer range than ever before.

articles.headline: For Sale on eBay: A Military Database of Fingerprints and Iris Scans
articles.snippet: German security researchers studying biometric capture devices popular with the U.S. military got more than they expected for $68 on eBay.
articles.abstract: German security researchers studying biometric capture devices popular with the U.S. military got more than they expected for $68 on eBay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shoebox-shaped device, designed to capture fingerprints and perform iris scans, was listed on eBay for $149.95. A German security researcher, Matthias Marx, successfully offered $68, and when it arrived at his home in Hamburg in August, the rugged, hand-held machine contained more than what was promised in the listing.
articles.byline: By Kashmir Hill, John Ismay, Christopher F. Schuetze and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Russian City Mourns Its Lost Soldiers, but Doesn’t Resent Putin’s War
articles.snippet: Ryazan, not far from Moscow, regularly sends young men off to fight. Some are now buried in the local cemetery, but there is no surge of outrage against Russian leaders.
articles.abstract: Ryazan, not far from Moscow, regularly sends young men off to fight. Some are now buried in the local cemetery, but there is no surge of outrage against Russian leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even under a thick coating of snow, the graveyard for Russian soldiers killed in the Ukraine war is awash in color. Graves are heaped with wreaths of plastic flowers and, at each mound, flags representing the dead soldier’s unit whip in the wind.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: ‘Most Pro-Union President’ Runs Into Doubts in Labor Ranks
articles.snippet: Many union leaders say the Biden White House has delivered on its promises. But its handling of a freight rail dispute has given rise to detractors.
articles.abstract: Many union leaders say the Biden White House has delivered on its promises. But its handling of a freight rail dispute has given rise to detractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. vowed to be “the most pro-union president you’ve ever seen.” And for the last two years, labor leaders have often lauded him for delivering on that promise.

articles.headline: Retirees Are One Reason the Fed Has Given Up on a Big Worker Rebound
articles.snippet: Workers are in short supply three years into the pandemic job market rebound, and officials increasingly think they aren’t coming back.
articles.abstract: Workers are in short supply three years into the pandemic job market rebound, and officials increasingly think they aren’t coming back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alice Lieberman had planned to work for a few more years as a schoolteacher before the pandemic hit, but the transition to hybrid instruction did not come easily for her. She retired in summer 2021.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: What Would It Take to Turn More Offices Into Housing?
articles.snippet: Vast amounts of empty real estate are a crisis for building owners. But some politicians and business leaders hope they can be converted into something new — and transform downtown neighborhoods.
articles.abstract: Vast amounts of empty real estate are a crisis for building owners. But some politicians and business leaders hope they can be converted into something new — and transform downtown neighborhoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s about 998 million square feet of office real estate across the United States that’s available but in search of a tenant.

articles.headline: ‘Tragic Battle’: On the Front Lines of China’s Covid Crisis
articles.snippet: Medical staff are outnumbered and working sick as the nation’s health care system buckles under the strain of a spiraling crisis.
articles.abstract: Medical staff are outnumbered and working sick as the nation’s health care system buckles under the strain of a spiraling crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slumped in wheelchairs and lying on gurneys, the sickened patients crowd every nook and cranny of the emergency department at the hospital in northern China. They cram into the narrow spaces between elevator doors. They surround an idle walk-through metal detector. And they line the walls of a corridor ringing with the sounds of coughing.
articles.byline: By Isabelle Qian and David Pierson

articles.headline: Southwest’s Debacle, Which Stranded Thousands, to Be Felt for Days
articles.snippet: Bad winter weather led the company to cancel more than 60 percent of its flights for Tuesday and Wednesday, leaving many travelers frustrated.
articles.abstract: Bad winter weather led the company to cancel more than 60 percent of its flights for Tuesday and Wednesday, leaving many travelers frustrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a winter storm pummeled many parts of the country, most airlines quickly bounced back from delays and cancellations. But not Southwest Airlines, which days later is still struggling from what executives and analysts describe as its biggest operational meltdown in its five-decade history.
articles.byline: By Isabella Simonetti and Peter Eavis
